The future of our climate and our economy can’t afford new oil and gas leasing, but that’s exactly what this new @forestservice rule will do. 

It’s a recipe for deeper droughts, hotter fires, and drying rivers.

Absolutely unconscionable.

Our national forests provide clean drinking water and clean air for millions of people. 

By slashing public review to expand drilling in national forests, Trump’s @forestservice rule puts human health at risk in the middle of a public health crisis.

On media bias:

I don't think we can dictate our opinions based on something we hear on cable networks. Additionally, it's a real shame that so much of our public opinion is based on a tweet or facebook post. It's upon ourselves to dig deeper and seek out unbiased information.

I compliment @GovHerbert's handling of #COVID19-- it's been hard to navigate. We've never seen this before and it has changed midstream. I think he's done a fabulous job at striking a balance and I applaud him turning some of the decisions over to local leaders such as mayors.

❓Thoughts on term limits for the House and Senate:

I'm a big fan of term limits. I've tried to limit myself in political office. I was having one of the best experiences of my life as Provo mayor but felt after eight years it was time for someone else to take over.

One of my bills I really like deals with energy storage, and I'm also working hard to promote clean technology overseas-- a real win-win if we can export clean U.S. tech. 

More info below and on my website:
https://curtis.house.gov/press-releases/curtis-introduces-clean-energy-incentivizing-invest-act/

❓How were your remarks at Sutherland received (link below)

I've been really pleased with the outpouring of texts, message, comments from those ready to dive into this discussion. Back in DC, some of my colleagues are ready to join me and some are not. 
https://curtis.house.gov/press-releases/confessions-of-a-climate-conservative/

❓: Is there a specific plan you support to reopen the schools?

A: I believe the decisions should stay local with mayors and school boards where the local community can have a say.

❓: Restart of nuclear tests in Utah

A: Clearly we've had bad experiences with nuclear testing here in the state. Perhaps there are places in the country where it's appropriate to test, but I'm not aware of anyone who would support that here in Utah.

To learn more about the climate science and resilience provisions in our @ClimateCrisis Action Plan please visit my website at https://bonamici.house.gov/ClimateActionPlan. #OregonClimateAction

We also recognize the need to scale up investments in climate science. Our @ClimateCrisis Action Plan includes provisions from my BLUE GLOBE Act & ICOOS Act to strengthen the use of satellites, buoys, underwater gliders, and tide gauges to deliver accurate & continuous ocean data

Our #ClimateActionPlan takes steps to #DefendScience by:
👩🏽‍🔬 directing federal agencies to use the best available science in decision making & implement scientific integrity policies
🏭 reinstating the Social Cost of Carbon, a metric to quantify climate damages from emissions

Our Plan will develop climate risk information at a local and regional level to help inform the development of strong resilience codes, specifications, and standards for our local communities.  I'm working to turn this concept into a bill that will help our coastal communities.

Our @ClimateCrisis Action Plan:
🌎 establishes a Nat'l Climate Adaptation Commission to better coordinate adaptation planning & provide technical assistance
📋creates a Tribal Government Task Force to provide equitable funding to Tribal Nations for climate adaptation & resilience

@nanoos_pnw @CRITFC @HatfieldMSC @MSI_OregonState @OSUCEOAS @OregonSeaGrant @ColumbiaEstuary @oregonsurfrider As wildfires rage across the west and the Gulf prepares to once again rebuild from immense storm damage from Hurricane Laura, it is clear that we must address the #ClimateCrisis and support frontline communities that have been disproportionately affected.

I continued my #OregonClimateAction tour with a virtual discussion with PNW leaders on climate science and resilience issues. I am grateful for their efforts to safeguard climate science from political interference and to help our communities adapt to the #ClimateCrisis. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EhBErm_WAAEzn6H.jpg

Our plan for #SolvingTheClimateCrisis focuses on the root of the problem: reducing emissions. But we also recognize that the effects of the climate crisis are already here & exacerbating social, racial, & economic inequalities. We need immediate adaptation and resilience policies

Whether you choose to vote by absentee ballot or in person, your ballot will be safe and be counted. #PlanYourVote and ensure your voice is heard in the 2020 General Election.

4. If you mail your absentee ballot, it must be postmarked by Election Day & received by your county clerk before the Canvass begins. Plan to mail or hand-deliver your absentee ballot to your County Clerk's office in time. Track your absentee ballot here: https://services.sos.wv.gov/Elections/Voter/AbsenteeBallotTracking

3. If you cannot vote in person, apply for an absentee ballot today. #COVID19 health concerns are an accepted reason to request an absentee ballot. For more information on eligibility for an absentee ballot, and to apply for an absentee ballot, click here: https://sos.wv.gov/elections/Pages/AbsenteeVotingInformation.aspx

2. Find your polling place: https://services.sos.wv.gov/Elections/Voter/FindMyPollingPlace Early voting is open Oct. 21-31 at your county courthouse, annex or designated community voting location during normal business hours & Saturdays 9AM to 5PM. On Election Day (Nov. 3), polling places are open 6:30AM-7:30PM.

1. Register to vote online, by mail, or at your County Clerk's office, or check the status of your voter registration: https://ovr.sos.wv.gov/Register/Landing The deadline to register and be eligible to vote in the 2020 General Election is close of business on October 13.

To teachers and school leaders: I first want to say what you don’t hear often enough—Thank you. You have the hardest, and most rewarding, job in the world. Now more than ever, you are helping shape the future of our country by creating opportunity for the next generation.

To parents: I know you are doing the best you can in impossible circumstances. Whatever your child’s learning environment is, the support you are providing is irreplaceable—and I’ll continue to fight to make sure schools have the resources to keep you and your families safe.

To students: stay motivated and lean on your teachers, friends, & families for support if you’re having a tough time. There’s nothing more important than you continuing to learn and grow. Life is constantly throwing us curveballs, and it’s how we respond that makes us who we are.

Before I was a senator, I was Superintendent of Denver Public Schools.
 
So I’ve been in your shoes—ready to start the First Day of School, nervous about everything going smoothly & excited for the learning that awaits. 

But this year, we never could have anticipated #COVID19.

To students, teachers, school leaders & parents: 

As you head #BackToSchool amidst #COVID19—whether in person, online, or with a hybrid model—know that your entire community stands behind you.
